Award.AwardTitle: Digitization TCN: Collaborative Research: The Key to the Cabinets: Building and Sustaining a Research Database for a Global Biodiversity Hotspot
Award.AbstractNarration:
The southeastern USA is botanically rich, with areas of high global biodiversity in both the Appalachians and the coastal plain. Millions of plant specimens have been collected from this region over the past four centuries, and these specimens and the information they contain currently reside in museums, or herbaria, at universities across the area. Scientists study these specimens intently; however, it is difficult to retrieve information at broad geographic and taxonomic scales without pipelines to move the information electronically from the specimen to an accessible pool of data. SERNEC, or the SouthEast Regional Network of Expertise and Collections, is a large regional network of botanical experts and collections that has, through an NSF-sponsored research coordination network (RCN) project, developed critical skills in biodiversity informatics. The current project will allow the SERNEC group to make data available for over 3 million specimens using the latest photography and information capture tools and to engage citizen scientists and students to assist in transcribing and georeferencing this large dataset. The research generated through this project can help regional planners, land managers and communities to manage their natural resources in our ever-changing environment.

The interaction of scientists, citizen scientists, and students will provide a synergy to build a research tool of an unparalleled scale and scope. The ultimate goal of this project is to develop an imaged and databased set of over 3 million specimens from over 100 herbaria in one of the most floristically diverse regions in North America and a global hotspot of plant diversity. This will represent a valuable data source for research on the response of vegetation to climate change, human development, and rapid migrations of introduced species. This region has been a biodiversity hotspot for 100 million years and this project should encourage research on changes over time to develop better predictive models as areas of biodiversity change. By partnering with Symbiota, Notes from Nature, GEOLocate, Adler Planetarium, iPlant/TACC, and Specify, the project will develop ways to best integrate various efforts for data accessibility. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program, and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Louisiana at Monroe was the lead institution for the NSF-BRC project ?CyberFlora Louisiana? funded from March 2009 through February 2013. That project attempted to image 1.1 million specimens in all 15 herbarium collections in the state and develop online access to the images. Two herbaria could not be imaged during the CyberFlora Louisiana project ? The University of New Orleans (NOLS) and Northwestern State University (NATC). Digitization of specimen labels was not completed during the CyberFlora project; therefore, this was one of the major goals for this SERNEC ADBC collaborative project. With digitization of the collection data, it would be possible to geo-reference southeastern US specimens within the collections, a primary goal of the collaborative project for the Southeast. An additional goal of this project was to transfer the images currently housed on the CyberFlora Louisiana server to SERNEC control and eventual transfer to iDigBio. This would provide long term stability and security of the Louisiana specimen information, as well as giving the collection wider distribution and availability worldwide.

The largest collection in Louisiana ? NLU ? was divested by the University of Louisiana at Monroe (ULM) administration in summer 2017 and transferred to the Botanical Research Institute of Texas (BRIT). The specimen images in the CyberFlora Louisiana database remained available to PI Sasek. Since NLU represents about half of the Louisiana specimens, more emphasis was placed on digitizing Southeastern labels from NLU in order to contribute more information to the collection transferred to BRIT. BRIT has initiated efforts to secure funding to digitize the remainder of the NLU collection. The recent divestments of the Tulane (NO) and LSUS herbaria to LSU also meant that LSU has a greater role in digitizing those labels, though not directly supported by this ADBC grant. The goal of geo-referencing specimens continued but at a reduced rate. 

In addition to testing the Notes from Nature citizen science method for digitizing specimen labels, efforts were made to develop a fast, efficient, and accurate procedure for digitizing labels from the images produced during the CyberFlora Louisiana project. The procedure involved cropping the label image from the specimen image and processing it through OCR software. Significant improvement was obtained by tweaking image processing of the label including contrast and magnification prior to OCR. Accuracy improved significantly with good quality labels, whether printed or typed. Labels of lesser quality were more difficult. The OCR output was then subjected to several text processing steps to make each field delimited by a paragraph mark to facilitate importing to a spreadsheet. Image processing and OCR was typically done as 100 specimens per spreadsheet. Using work-study student labor, the data in each row was adjusted so that each data field aligned in the same column. Once aligned, it was possible to look up and down a column to fix any typos or differences in style or format. Once complete and verified, the spreadsheet data could be uploaded to the SERNEC portal.
